item.description:
Quick play English Civil War wargame played with regiments of foot comprising of 18 figures and cavalry comprising of 6 figures. The turn sequence is activated by cards, and units move and shoot using a straightforward system. There is no casualty removal until a full base has been destroyed. Ideal for 28mm plastic ECW games.

Includes special events for each game, and a variety of optional rules. Rather than an in depth analysis of Seventeenth Century warfare, Victory Without Quarter plays as a pleasant game with toy soldiers, without getting bogged down in too much detail.

name.value: Too Few To Fight, Too Many To Die

item.description:
Rules for the North American Indian Wars, covering the period from the French and Indian War to the last stand of the Sioux at Wounded Knee. The Eastern Woodland, Plains, Rocky Mountain and South-Western tribes and their British, French, Spanish, Mexican and American opponents are all catered for. Based on the mechanisms used in Death In The Dark Continent.

The game aims to represent fairly large scale battles instead of the skirmishes usually played out with Wild West games. The rules come complete with a quick reference section, contents list, and army lists for all the major combatants.

Try to collect your house (9 pieces), buy it, fix the mortgage get the key.
Game published for a real estate company.
Game material :
1 game board, 72 cards (36 black & 36 green), 4 pawns and 1 dice.
By going around the boards outer ring, you must collect cards which you can save (to assemble a complete house set for which you receive a key card) of to discard.
After that you have to collect a buy card and an mortgage card, together with the key card and by doing this claim the win.

Publisher's description:

It is a board game with a story that goes along with it. Six teenagers dare each other to stay overnight in the spooky Dread House in their neighborhood. And in this game, the house really is haunted!

Dread House is a horror game for spooky children and brave adults. It's a role-playing board game in which you play teenagers who've dared each other to spend the night in Dread House.

Who will run home to their mommy?

What thing yet lives in the mansion?

Will the sunrise ever come?

Only you can answer these questions.

Your PDF will come with:


 The Rule Book;
 Six Character Sheets;
 Six Monster Sheets;
 Six Monster Cards;
 A deck of 22 Spooky Events;
 A deck of 22 Useful Items;
 And a map of Dread House (in three parts).


Some assembly and a Jenga set required.

As the teens explore the house, the players draw cards and describe to each other spooky things the characters see and useful things they discover. Each teen has special abilities that can help them explore and help each other stand up to the Monsters.

The teenagers are scared by many things in the house. When their character is scared, the players pull blocks from a Tower of blocks to see if their character stays in the Dread House. If the Tower falls when someone pulls, that person gets to play a Monster in the house who scares the others.

If half the kids get scared away, the Monsters win and the teens have to try another time to prove their bravery. But if the card for the Sunrise is found while enough kids are still in the house, they have made it through the night!

Civil War Commander is a card game, in which you are a Brigidier General for either the Union or the Confederate army. You have command of 5 regiments consisting of infantry companies, artillery batteries, and cavalry troops. 
 Your mission is to hold 5 sectors of terrian either by defending or capturing them. How you deploy your given troops, how you use your reserves, and the abilities of your regimental commanders will determine the outcome.
 Win and you'll be a hero and may be promoted. Lose and you may be removed from command. Such is the life of a CIVIL WAR COMMANDER.

(From Publishers Website)

item.description: In "É Hora de Votar!", players assume the role of voters and politicians. Each round, two players try to win the votes of the others, by promising to build parks, schools, hospitals etc. But everybody has a secret agenda, and to win an election a player must try to do what the majority of the voters want. The first player to complete all his secret and open goals wins the game (text created by the game's designer).

item.description: "Bakugan: Torneio dos Mundos" is a contest to see which player can win more tournaments in the 6 worlds of "Bakugan Battle Brawlers". Each round, a world is randomly chosen. Players then select one Bakugan card from their hands, and then one "special effects" card. All variables are added up and the owner of the most powerful Bakugan places a token on the world where the tournament was played. The first player to achieve a number of victories wins the game (text by the game's designer).

PocketStalingrad is a print-and-play game for two players (see the files section below). By David Laufle The game is free, and might even fit in your pocket. 
It's 1942 in war torn Russia, head into the besieged city of Stalingrad and fight your way to victory in 30-45 minutes. The game uses several dice. Roll the dice and set aside unit deployment, tactics, events or command points, using at least one die per roll. Add units to the 5 major city locations or to Gumrak Airfield or the Volga Crossing, add in Fortifications, Pioneers, snipers, infiltration, Luftwaffe attacks, night, Guards and more; and you have yourself a battle.
Control of 3 of the 5 major locations by turn 5 is a winner, otherwise the most City Areas wins.

item.description:
The game is based on a Japanese light novel, Durarara!!
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durarara!!

One of the 500-yen games produced at Game Market 2010 in Tokyo, Japan. The deck consists of 15 each of three different color cards without numbers. These three colors represent three factions. You play and draw almost all the cards in front of you. The last three cards in your hand determine which faction you belong to: Blue, Red, Yellow or Daraas. You only score points if the faction you belong to is the one that most number of players belong to. In that case, you score the number of non-faction colors in front of you (For Daraas, the scores are fixed points). Clever little game.

There are 5 pet shops in the game, each offering a specific pet (dogs, cats, rabbits, parrots and chameleons). Players are trying to amass the largest collection of pets by claiming pets from the pet shops.

The game is played over a several rounds, each of which goes through the following 4 phases:
1. Supply - The pet shops randomly gains new pets.
2. Donation - The players each donate a new born pet to the respective pet shop.
3. Claim - The players attempt to claim older pets that the pet shops are giving away by bidding. Pet shops give away older pets to the first customer that wants them. However if more than one customer wants to claim the same pet, they will decide to keep the pet to avoid a confrontation. However, if one of the claimants can provide a more conducive shelter for the pet, he will be given the pet during a confrontation. This phase will recur until all the pets in the shops are given away or the players all decide to stop claiming pets.
4. Birth - The players' pets give birth to new born pets.

Play continues through the 4 phases in each round recurrently until the deck runs out.

At the end of the game, players tally the number of pets they have as well as check who has the most shelters for each type of the pet. The player with the most shelters for each type of pet takes a penalty(loses some pets) as they are deemed to have too many shelters and thus insufficient space for the pets to live comfortably. The players with the most pets for each pet type gains a bonus (gains more pets of that type). After applying the penalties and bonuses, the player with the most pets win.

item.description:
Back of the Box:

Players are rulers of rival kingdoms. Everyone wants to develop its power to the best of his ability and at the same time undermine and thwart the plans of the rival.

Each player, during the game, will build five stacks of cards in front of his/her, one representing each facet of his/her reign:

- Buildings 
- Army 
- Espionage 
- Commerce 
- Knowledge

For each category there are three types of cards:

- Score cards (points)
- Attack cards (delete the score cards)
- Defence cards (protect from the attack)
 Some Attack and Defence cards don’t belong to a specific category, but have instead show a jester(Mercenary). Those cards can be played on any of the five stacks, to the player’s will.

The game ends when a player has a score card in the top of each category, or when a player's deck is empty.

Each player sum all valid score cards and the extra points earned by combinations. Who have more points is the winner.

(by automatic translator from Chinese)

WZY 2010 Board Game Awards - Best 2-Player Game (China)

The two players (German and Allies) will chase each other on a chess like board.

The game contains :

item.description:
From the back of the box:
Actual inscription on a NJ tombstone: "I told you I was sick. And get off my grave."
FACT or FICTION?
In this fast-paced trivia game, your aim is to blitz the competition and amaze them with your knowledge about the local legends and best kept secrets of the State of New Jersey.

From the day to day, to the truly bizarre, you will be asked the one question that really counts -- is it FACT or FICTION?

Watch out for the crazy Rush Hour where you can earn double points if you're fast enough and if you stop laughing for long enough.

Take the challenge, put on your thinking cap, and remember: it comes down to two words -- FACT or FICTION!

item.description:
Hyves was the biggest social network website in The Netherlands with around 10 million accounts at its peak.

In this social board game it is all about one thing; how good do your friends know you and how good do you know your friends? During the game the players roll the die to see which subject card they will have to play. In turns a player puts the 5 options of a subject card in the order that fits this player's personality best while the other players try to predict which order the first player puts down. For each correct answer a player receives points which will be noted by the pawn on the playing board and on the special score card on which also other important information can be found (like which player is the 'most open book').

item.description:
This pirate themed boardgame came with the Swedish comic magazine Kalle Anka & C:o (Donald Duck) in the issues #6 to #11 1977.
Each player controls a pirateship which all start in the common harbour.
The players use startmoney to purchase treasure maps which are kept hidden from the other players during the game. 
The players then set sails to dig up the treasuechests at various locations on the board which are pictured on the maps. 
Treasures are worth different amounts of money which are secret for all players until they are found.
The players try to return to the harbour with the treasurechests but the other pirates have the possibility to capture treasures before they return to the harbour by boarding them and engaging in ship to ship combat.
Battles are resolved by rolling a custom made spinner.
When all treasures are found the pirate with most money wins!

The game was later the same year published in the German comic magazine Micky Maus in the issues #36 to #38 1977 as Micky Maus Piratenspiel.

Prepare yourself for a fierce duel. Cleverly use the features of the four different families to snatch the most valuable gangsters away from your opponent. Your goal? To have the best gang at the end of the game.

In Famiglia, the players collect gangsters with the goal of collecting the highest-valued gangsters. With the exception of the 0-value gangsters, a player normally needs two identical gangsters (same family and same value) to be able to take a gangster with the next highest value of the same family. When a player does this, they place one of the smaller gangsters from their hand into their play area. To get higher-valued gangsters faster, the player may use the special abilities of the different families at the cost of placing more gangsters in their play area. By doing so, a player may reduce their options and so must carefully plan these actions in order to end the game with the most influential gang.

item.description:
Smart Investor is a card game that simulates the stock trading. Players are dealt a random set of stocks worth 500€ - and for winning the game you have to increase the value of your portfolio with four rounds as much as possible. During the course of the rounds, players buy and sell stocks, which impacts the price. Just remember that every stock you sell decreases the stock value... but every company's first stock you buy increases the value. If one particular stock in sector/industry raises high enough in value, market bubble follows with raising other stocks as well... but beware of market crashes!

Therefore - for being successful in "Smart Investor" you have to know when to buy, when to sell and when to do nothing more but wait. Just like in real life, isn't it?

This is a 10x10 chess variant with a unique mix of pieces. The king, rook, knight, and pawn are common to chess and shatranj. The hero and shaman are short range pieces easily as powerful as the rook on a 10x10. These two inclusive compound pieces may step one and/or jump 2 squares, either or both, in either order, changing direction between step and leap if desired, with the hero moving orthogonally and the shaman diagonally. The final piece in the game is a war elephant, the equivalent of an unchained padwar from Jetan, a piece that may move 1 or 2 squares diagonally, changing direction if desired between the first and second steps. The combination of strong and weak pieces, of different ranges and abilities, allows a strategically and tactically rich game with piece balance and variety. The opposed pairs of hero vs rook and shaman vs war elephant provide an intricate series of checks and balances between the pieces.

Wythoff's game is a nim-like game played with two piles of counters. Players take turns to remove counters from one or both piles, with the winner removing the last stone. The Dutch mathematician W. A. Wythoff published a mathematical analysis of the game in 1907.

A Nim-like game where players take turns to split big piles into two smaller piles, with different numbers of things in each pile. The game ends when only piles of size one or two are left, and the winner is the last to make a move.

Wikipedia link

item.description:
Split Decision is a trivia game featuring X-or-Y pairings. You'll be presented with a word or phrase, and you have to decide which it is: A Discontinued Ben & Jerry's Flavor or a Band We Found on MySpace? A Presidential Nickname or a Professional Wrestler? A Celebrity Baby Name or a Computer Virus? A line from Doogie Howser's Diary or a Random Twitter Update?

Get it right, fill in a circle on your scoring pad. First person to fill up his or her card wins!

Mixed in are Challenge Cards, where you ask one person three straight trivia questions. When you draw one of these cards, you'll be instructed who to challenge -- "Challenge the Person Who's Gotten the Most Speeding Tickets" or "Challenge the Best Person to Cheat Off in Chemistry Class" -- and the questions are related to that theme.

In addition to, you know, being fun, we think you'll learn a whole lot of cool stuff each time you play. Stuff you'll later wow someone with when you casually drop it into conversation.

(Info from direct from Publisher/Designer)

Using a derivation of the system premiered in Kings of Pools Waterpolo, Olympic Field Hockey (subtitled Running with Sticks over Grass) is fast play statistical replay game on Field Hockey, with data for replaying all Olympic Tournaments from 1948 onward, both men and women.
To resolve each game you need only a couple of dice rolls, so you may replay an entire tournament in less than an hour.
For each match, compare the attack and the defense values of both teams, and roll two six sided dice for each, to get the final result of a match. But there is also the "infamous" Third Die, a 10 sided die whose result may dramaticaly alter the result of the match, making a win by an underdog team at least possible, even against the best of the best.

This is a party game promoting Viennese culture. There are six categories in which the two teams compete, like charade, imitating celebrities, using the other team's players as "puppets" to depict a scene, etc.
The other team and one referee decide about the success of a task - a successful team can keep the card. When one team has completed a task from each of the six categories, the game ends and the team which has most cards wins.

The game was apparently distributed for free in Vienna.

Cartouche is Small Box Games' Pure Card Line game.

2-4 players take on the role of a ruler of ancient Egypt in this textless deckbuilding card game. This compact game includes 144 cards in six different decks.

Each card belongs to one of six deity decks. Players draft a small initial Dynasty deck of six cards, and as the game progresses, players use their originally drafted cards to gain additional cards to add to their decks and attempt to ruin other player's plans of the perfect Dynasty.

Every card may be used to take cards from one of six Deity decks, or its special ability may be used. Additionally, each card has the potential to add or subtract from the player's score at the end of the game. The player with the greatest Dynasty scores the most points and wins the game.

item.description:
With the new hero-game "Quest" players experience exciting adventures at the gaming table, that unfold just like a cinematic tale.

In a chain of exciting quests, most players take on the role of heroes while another player is their antagonist - the Questmaster. He controls all the challenges that the other players cooperatively have to master with the clever use of their skills and abilities.

Each of the quests build up on the previous ones and through the course of the campaign both the Questmaster and the players become stronger and therefore the gaming-experience more intense.

The personal development of the heroes through the course of several games will be continued with further expansions, that will add new heroes, more quests, more abilities and new dire enemies.

item.description:
A free download-and-print board game released in response to the 'Ground Zero Mosque' looniness.

From the game board: "Many people thought the attacks of 9/11 were about terror, but the truth is far more sinister. Yesterday, extreme Muslimists built a Giant Mosque, planted like a victory flag, at Ground Zero. That's right, the flattening of the World Trade Center nine years ago was part of a broader Islamofacist terror plot designed to circumvent local planning laws and lower the notoriously expensive NYC ground rent at the same time. Why? So that the entirety of downtown Manhattan can be turned into the world's biggest mosque - a project they refer to as The Giant Mosqtapus. If we don't stop this Megamosque now, it's tentacles will strangle the life out of this, the greatest city, in the greatest country on earth. Only you can stop Mosqopoly!"

What the hell are monkeys doing in your living room?
Who will get the most bananas?
A primitive mime game, made of bizarre and crazy positions
Different game modes between adults and children.

In Monkey See Monkey Do in each turn a player has to mime something, and all the other players must
guess what he/she is miming.
By guessing and miming, each player will gain Penitences. Each Penitence will oblige players to assume
bizarre positions while performing their following mimes, making the game harder and more fun along the
way.
The objective is simple: collect as many Penitences as possible, before the mimes are over.

item.description:
From the publisher:

The biggest Napoleonic game ever, for the largest Napoleonic battle

The battle of Leipzig was the largest battle of the Napoleonic wars and the largest battle in Europe until the First World War easily ranking as one of the largest battles in History. 
Leipzig is a huge battle, as the battlefield is more than 15 km wide, and a very long battle, as the events spread over 6 days between October 14th and October 19th, 1813. The French eventually gather around 190,000 men, against 350,000. It is a succession of ferocious and quite independent battles. The Allied plan, although inelegant, proved to be successful as the odds allowed them to attack everywhere and keep the advantage. Even though using the interior lines, Napoleon was rarely in a position to take a serious strategic advantage while winning almost every of these battles because a 1:2 odd can not lead to a decisive victory against determined enemies.

However, you are now in charge of the army, and things can turn very different...

"Vive l’Empereur!" is a series of simulation games using a standard rules system and a set of exclusive rules specific to each battle. These particular rules include an historical commentary and the victory conditions for each scenario. 
The aim of this system is to refight at the regimental scale the numerous battles fought during the Napoleonic Era in Europe, between 1805 and 1815. It uses a map on which the players move counters representing the combat units involved in these battles.

Hikone Carom is the variety of Carrom that is played in Japan.

There are some key differences between Hikone Carrom and Carrom.

--The standard board size is 60cm x 60cm, which makes it smaller than standard Carrom boards.

--The pockets of a Hikone Carrom board are large quarter-circles, making the pockets bigger than in Carrom.

--The strikers are wooden and are the same size as the pucks in Hikone Carom.

--In initial set up, the pucks are arranged in a ring with the jack in the center.

Description of the history of Hikone Carom from Wikipedia:

Carrom was introduced to Japan in the last years of the Meiji period or TaishÅ period by someone from the UK and in the early ShÅwa period by someone from the USA. In the middle ShÅwa period, carrom was called "fighting ball board" or "tossing ball board" (é—˜çƒç›¤ or æŠ•çƒç›¤, tÅkyÅ«ban?) and was a popular board game throughout Japan. Carrom gradually lost popularity, but is still played in Hikone, Shiga. In Hikone, carrom is called karomu (ã‚«ãƒ­ãƒ ?) and many homes have their own carrom boards and use derivative rules. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrom#Japanese_carrom)

item.description:
Board game about Estonian fens nature.

In Estonian fens there are many interesting animals, birds, insects and plants.A group of explorers have made a decision to go to fen and find most interesting species. Moving in fen isn`t easy, You have to build boardwalks and observation platforms. But you have to be careful because any time can come freshet an destroy your roads and platforms.

On the game board there are 81 squares (9 X 9), in the middle of the board there is a starting square and the rest of the board is partly covered by 12 squares with animals, birds, insects and so on. At the start players must divvy up these 12 squares and then they start to build roads from starting square to the animals, birds, insects that they've got. For that they use various road tiles. Player who connect all of his squares with animals, birds, insects to the starting square is the winner.

OMEGA was born as an experiment on complexity and intuitive arithmetic. Both concepts teamed up to create this little monster. It feels like a cross between Hex and Go.

In OMEGA, players try to create groups of their colors by placing stones in a hexagonal grid, in order to score the most points. But each player places stones of all colors in play.

The final score for each color is calculated by multiplying the sizes of the different groups of that color.

Thanks to the 6 acrylic 'corners' included in the game, it can be played on various board sizes. From 5-hexes side to 10-hexes side. Other board shapes can be configured, too.

You will soon realize that you don´t need to calculate your score during play (multiplying your group values). Use an intuitive strategy instead. How? You must figure it out by yourself.

2-player games of size beyond 8 are only recommended for experienced players and scores are often gigantic.

OMEGA was initially designed for 2 players. The designer then added the 3 and 4 player option, but the gameplay is completely different.

item.description: "The devastating knockout. The expertly-executed submission. The blood, the drama, the upsets. All are present in Alex Williams Strike or Submit (S!O!S!): A Game of Mixed Martial Arts Combat. In S!O!S!, players use chart-and-dice (in a non-computerized format) to take control of their favorite mixed martial arts (MMA) fighters and pit them against one another in full-contact fights. Want to have Fedor fight Arlovski; Rickson battle Sakuraba; play out the latest Grand Prix tournament? All of this is possible in the most accurate and fun MMA game to date!" - From strikeorsubmit.tripod.com

Overview from game designer:-

Attercop is a new board game where two players take on the roles of Attercop and Meratoo. Meratoo is the hapless spider who must cross the web of Attercop. Meratoo, must gently feel his way across the web before being caught. Hidden, Attercop stalks - probing, deceiving, sneaking for her prey.

It's devious, it's cunning, it's sneaking good fun !

How the game is played, from game designer :-

Attercop is a game for two players. One player is Attercop, a spider with a reputation for cunning, and a lady with an appetite. The other is Meratoo, a little spider nervously trying to cross her web. The aim of the game is for Meratoo to make his way from one side of the web to the other, whilst Attercop tries to catch him.

The web consists of 44 connected points, each covered by a "blank" tile. Meratoo travels from blank tile to blank tile, gently feeling his way accross the Web trying to avoid running into Attercop. Meanwhile, Attercop has a number of tiles to represent her legs, which tease the web and try to bluff the Meratoo player into her grasp, by being able the change the position of the tiles on the web. Here's the catch: the Attercop tiles remain face-down on the web, undistinguishable from the blank tiles, and they can be moved along with the rest of the web tiles. This is how Attercop probes her way around the web.

For Attercop the game is all about bluffing and enticing Meratoo into her grasp. For Meratoo it is all about staying alert, testing the web and calling Attercop's bluff. The game is fun to play, generates lots of laughs , is a light-hearted and quick game, and is great for both kids and adults.

In Florenza, the players are the heads of the most powerful families in Florenza during the Renaissance period. The goal of the game is to become the most famous patron of the arts by hiring the most famous artists of the period and financing their works.

Each player can commission artworks in his own district, the Cathedral, or in the civic buildings of the city. Each artwork requires money and resources to complete. To earn the money and resources the artists need, the players send their workers to labor in various workshops, possibly even in their opponents’ districts. Additional workers can be earned by offering charity to the church. During the game, players will earn prestige points, primarily by completing artworks. prestige points can be spent during the game, but at the end of the game they will be the player’s primary source of victory points.

All of the characters in the game are real historical figures that lived and worked in Italy during the Renaissance. Most of them worked in Florence. All of the buildings in the game were real Renaissance workshops. The artworks the players can complete include the masterpieces of some of the most famous artists in the world.

Note from the designers directly from the rulebook:

"We apologize if we included some characters in the game who never worked in Florence during the Renaissance, but we wanted to include all of the most important artists (in our opinion) from that golden age of Italian art and culture. Michelangelo, for example, left an important mark on the history of the city—and the Renaissance period—even if he was only in Florence for a short time. We also added some portraits of military leaders (created by Ivan Zoni) to the rulebook. They are not involved in the game, but they were influential members of public life during this era.
The names of the buildings, parts of the Cathedral, and the workshops are in the literal form they had in Italy during the 1400-1600 period. Some of them are unchanged in the modern Italian language, some have changed a little, and others have completely disappeared or remain only in some dialects. We chose to maintain those words, without translating them into a language that the real artists didn’t know. We hope you agree with our choice, and we hope you have a good time playing Florenza!"

name.value: Het Groot Van Dale Spel der Nederlandse Taal: Jeugd

item.description:
Het Groot Van Dale spel der Nederlandse Taal is a word game based on the major dictionary of the Dutch language. It consists of a board over which the players move their pawns, answering questions pertaining to the Dutch language, in the fields of word knowledge and spelling. Correct answers earn dictionary markers which are put under the pawn. Depending on whether a player has one, two or three dictionaries, the questions become increasingly difficult, making the end game a challenge. The game ends when a player reaches the finish space on the board while having three dictionary markers.

Het Groot Van Dale Spel der Nederlandse Taal Jeugd is especially made for children at the elementary school.

The abstract game Law & Chaos combines careful placement of "stones" on a board with changing victory conditions and capture methods, controlled in considerable part by the players. You can either place a stone, or play a victory method or capture method card that changes either one of your methods, one of another player's methods, or one of the shared methods. You have to try to build your position while interfering with others by placement or capture, anticipating what they may be trying to do.

It is that rare thing, a highly-interactive, natural three-player game, but can also be played by two or four.

Yamodo Party Time is the award-winning game of made-up words that will keep everyone laughing. Played in quick rounds, players scramble to create their “best” definition to a made-up word and theme with the hope of being picked by the judge. Be creative, be quick, but when time runs out, the Spindoodler is spun, and the consequences (like having to pass your card) only add to the fun. Write a funny definition, add a quick doodle, and feel free to lobby the judge on why your definition is best. Every round has a new judge, word and theme, so you never know what your mind will draw out!

[Source: Yamodo.com]

Each player in turn places a stone on the playing field on any free tile of their choice.
Players can gain points during the game by ending a row and at the end of the game for each row of 4 or more stones of their own colour. The player with the most points wins. There is also a game variant with bonus points for the experienced player.

Ihr legt abwechselnd einen Spielstein auf ein freies Feld des Spielfeldes. Immer wenn ihr dadurch eine Reihe komplettiert, bekommt ihr sofort Siegpunkte. Am Spielende erhaltet ihr zusätzliche Siegpunkte, für jede Reihe in der 4 oder mehr eigene Spielsteine auf direkt benachbarten Feldern liegen. Für erfahrene Spieler gibt es auch noch eine Variante mit Bonuspunkten.

Sur le plateau de jeu variable, les joueurs posent à tour de rôle une pierre sur une case libre. Les joueurs gagnent des points pendant le jeu lorsqu’ils ferment une rangée et à la fin du jeu ils reçoivent des points lorsqu’ils ont aligné 4 pierres ou plus de leur couleur. Celui qui obtient le plus de points remporte la partie. Pour les joueurs avancés, il y a aussi un jeu avec des points bonus.

Op het variabele speelveld leggen de spelers om de beurt een steen op een vrij legveld. Zij verdienen tijdens het spel punten voor het afsluiten van een rij en aan het eind van het spel punten voor 4 of meer stenen op een rij van de eigen kleur. Wie de meeste punten haalt, wint het spel. Voor de liefhebbers is er ook nog een spel met bonuspunten.

item.description:
Füttere die Tiere (Feed the animals) is an eays pick-up and deliver game 
It´s designed to teach children which animal likes which food.

At the beginning, the plyers draw animal cards, which show, what kind of food the animals want. This food can be found on the board (a farm). The players run around the farm in order to collect all food tokens, necessary to feed thier animals. The first player to fulfill all needs of his animals is the winner.

The playing time can be varied by the number of animal cards per player.

item.description:
From the back ot the box:
The total battle begun and only one of the fighters will get the world champion’s belt. Will you be the winner?
Use your cards to avoid your opponent’s attacks or to launch your own one. Use your special skills, and weapon’s cards, at the right time to emerge victorious and be the last player to be eliminated from Total Rumble. Become the best of the best!!!

In this lively, fast to play game, you become a powerful wrestler with special skills for the fight. Use your cards and objects (like chairs, ladders) to eliminate your opponents running their life’s points out.
Study your strategy and keep your best cards in your hand to respond your opponent’s attack and give them back a stronger attack, until one of the players can’t play any card and take damage from the blow.
The winner is the last wrestler standing, who will receive the World Champion’s Belt that will be able to use in next matches to raise your power.
Prove your abilities against 11 others players and be the best.

item.description:
Canvas is a connection game which bears a slight resemblance to the game of Amazons.

Canvas is played on a base 7 hex hex with its edges colored to designate ownership of the sides.

Objective: The objective of Canvas is to create a chain of your own stones and painters connecting your two opposite sides of the board

Gameplay: Starting with white, players alternate moving their painters and placing stones. On a player's turn he may move a painter in a straight line in any of the 6 directions any number of spaces. When the painter has finished moving, the player must either place a stone of his color on an adjacent space to the painter or he may transmit the stone to any space adjacent to a contiguous chain of stones of his own color (not other painters of the same color) that the painter touches. Painters may move over any number of stones of either color but may not land on a space occupied by a stone. Painters are not permitted to move over each other. Moving a painter is not mandatory but placing a stone is. A player cannot divide the moving and placing phases between two painters. A player must pass if he has no legal moves on his turn.

The pie rule is used to make the game fair.

name.value: Klaus die Maus entdeckt das Jahr

item.description:
The game board is ring-shaped and depicts a calendar, i.e. fields for each month. The players put their pieces in their birth month; Klaus the mouse starts in the current month. The playing pieces are birthday cakes (Klaus is an actual mouse). Eleven picture tiles are placed openly into the center of the board.

The active player first checks whether there are any gifts under his/her cake. If so, the player has to say which month the gift(s) belong(s) to - if right (the color code on the backside tells the answer), the player can keep the gift. If wrong, the player has to put the gift under another player's cake.

Afterwards, Klaus is moved by a die. The active player picks a tile from the middle that matches the month Klaus moved to and keeps it (if there is no matching tile or the player makes a mistake, the tile is given away as above). When Klaus passes a player, he gives that player another tile as a gift.

When all tiles have been distributed, the player with most tiles is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

The DIGIMON D-TECTOR CARD GAME is an offshoot from the Digimon Collectible Card Game. The cards are compatible with the D-TECTOR digital device, but also allow a typical CCG game. 
The D-TECTOR device is apparently quite rare in the USA.
The game allows players to collect and battle with Digimon. There are 4 Card types, Digimon, Digivolve, Digi-modify, and Digi-Destined. There are also 4 sub-types of Digimon, Rookie, Ultimate, Champion, & Mega. The Goal of the game is to defeat the opponent's Digimon, and gain Data Points.

A penguin holds a tray on which "ice" blocks are stacked up in a Jenga-like fashion. After each move, a player has to press a button and the penguin might (or might not) get cold and shake. If the shaking leads to blocks falling down, the active player has to stack them up on top again. If the entire tower topples, the last player before the active player is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

link.value: CCP Games / CCP hf (Crowd Control Productions)

item.description:
Boardgame about the Way of St. James. The players try to be the first to reach Santiago de Compostela with 10 stamps of different stations along the way. Basic movement is dice-driven. To proceed faster, the players have to answer trivia questions about the pilgrimage. Event cards add an element of luck. 
Each player can choose a means of transportation (horse/feet/bicycle). There is a spinning arrow which determines the weather - each type of weather influences the speed depending on the means of transportation.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Card game based on the Way of St. James. The game consists of cards which have photos of places along the pilgrimage route on one side; and trivia questions on the other side. 
Four cards are placed on the table, picture side up. Each player receives three cards at the beginning and must try to be the first one to get a consecutive set of eight cards (10 with 2 or 3 players).
The active player chooses a card from the four on the table that he/she would like to have. Another player then reads one of the questions on the back to him/her (the number of the question is determined by the position of the card on the table, i.e. 1-4 positions away from the draw pile). If answering correctly, the player can keep the card; if wrong, the card is discarded. A new card then replaces the old one. 
No player may hold more than 12 cards; excess cards have to be discarded. There are also some wild cards which help complete the sets.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

55 cards

First print run limited to 3,000 copies.

Children's version of the Austrian classic DKT. The game works monopoly-like: players roll dice and walk around the board, following instructions from cards, buying, selling or paying others. Besides money, there is another form of currency: entrance tickets. These can be used to pay other players, but also have to be collected to exchange them for money. 
The game is theme park-themed, so players buy and run rides.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

item.description:
The game is designed to train first graders' addition skills. The players take tiles from their hand which show either points or plus or minus. The active player has to add sheep to the current total or substract some, but never going above the limits 0 and 10 or 20. The current sum is shown by sheep tiles. A player who manages that gets a fox, a player who doesn't gets nothing and a player who makes a mistake has to return a fox. The player with most foxes at the end of the game is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name.value: Bibi Blocksberg: La mare aux crapauds ensorcelée

item.description:
Witch Bibi Blocksberg has been naughty, so her witching utensils have been thrown into a pond. The players have to help her to retrieve the items.

Bibi's items (colored chips) are placed on the board (in the pond). The black chips are placed next to the board.

The active player rolls two color dice. If a die shows white, the player loses a turn. If a die shows black, the player takes a black chip. In all other cases, the player can either take two chips in the color that he/she rolled, or all the chips between two chips of the right colors. If there is no more chip of a color rolled, the player has to place one of his/her own chips on the board.

When the last black chip has been taken, the game ends. The player who has retrieved most items is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name.value: Bibi Blocksberg: Cache-cache ensorcelé dans les nuages
Bibi Blocksberg: Il nascondiglio stregato tra le nuvole

item.description:
The players try to form a row of five cards which depict Bibi Blocksberg and her friend gradually appearing out of the clouds. 
The active player places a card face-down on a small seesaw-catapult, then hits the other end. If the card lands on the table and is face-up, he/she can check if it fits into his/her row. If it doesn't fit, it is discarded. If it doesn't land face-up, the next player adds it to his/her own card when firing the catapult, so he/she has a chance of multiple cards landing face-up. 
The first player to complete a row is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Making every move count!

An educational game to practice algebra (Sum, subtraction, multiplication & division)

Contents: 56 cards, 3 (six sided) Dice and 1 hourglass
(Dice: blue 0-2-3-4-5-8, blue 20-30-40-50-60-70, black 30-50-70-80-90-110)

Rules:
5 cards (showing numbers) are laid out open on the table, roll both the blue dice. Now every player tries to combine the numbers on the cards, to get the result equal to the diceroll.

When the hourglass is empty, an additional card is added to the open cards on the table. If a player is able to get the correct result, he takes the cards, with the numbers used, those are points for the end of the game.

The rules contain alternative rules to make the game more and less difficult.

Rules are in Dutch, French and German

item.description:
THE OFFICIAL LICENSED BOARD GAME
The circuits are divided into squares, and players will advance their bikes through the speed charts. Each card indicates the cells to move. But beware of the curves, overtaking and braking and will cause damage to the bikes, not some cards allow you to use and can remove you from the race.

The winning bike will be the first to reach the finish line after making three full turns to the circuit. But note that the winner will be the one who achieves the highest score with his team

COMPONENTS
-A Table-MotoGP board with the circuit of Jerez on one side and that of Qatar on the other.
-18 reproductions of MotoGP bikes with the colors and numbers runners.
-Letters 18 pilot to control the resistance, corresponding to each of the bikes.
-92 Letters of speed to move the bikes on the circuit. His numbers represent the number of boxes you can move 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9. In addition, special cards "?" That let you choose the speed of 5-9.
-4 dice rolls for resistance.


Los circuitos están divididos en casillas, y los jugadores avanzarán sus motos mediante las cartas de velocidad. Cada carta indica las casillas a moverse. Pero ten cuidado con las curvas, los adelantamientos y las frenadas ya que causarán desperfectos en las motos, no te permitirán usar algunas cartas y pueden eliminarte de la carrera.

La moto ganadora será la primera que llegue a la línea de meta tras realizar 3 vueltas completas al circuito. Pero, ten en cuenta que el ganador será aquel que obtenga la mejor puntuación con su escudería.

COMPONENTES
-Un tablero Table-MotoGP con el circuito de Jerez por un lado y el de Qatar por el otro.
-18 reproducciones de Motos de Moto-GP con los colores y números de los corredores.
-18 Cartas de piloto para controlar su resistencia, correspondientes a cada una de las motos.
-92 Cartas de velocidad para avanzar las motos sobre el circuito. Su numeración representa la cantidad de casillas que se puede avanzar: 5, 6, 7, 8 y 9. Además las cartas especiales “?” que permiten elegir la velocidad de 5 a 9.
-4 dados para realizar las tiradas de resistencia.

item.description:
Disaster on Everest is a solitaire game of climbing to the summit of Mt. Everest. Your goal is to use your guides to move clients up and down the mountain safely before the storm arrives. Each turn, you are limited in the number of climbers you can move. Guides can move clients farther, but your clients outnumber your guides. An event chit is drawn that must be either purchased out of a limited amount of Prestige Points or it goes on the Storm Track, hastening the arrival of the storm. The storm phase decreases movement and increases the difficulty of managing the clients.

Points are scored for clients that reach the summit and live to return to base camp.

From the publisher:

As the owner of an exotic travel company that specializes in extreme sporting activities, you provide clients with a way to reach the top of the world, Mt. Everest. Unfortunately, several other competing agencies have opened up, each with the goal of becoming the most prestigious and successful travel company.

You control the guides and clients attempting a dangerous ascent to the summit of Everest as a deadly storm approaches. The more clients that reach the summit and live to tell the tale, the greater your company's prestige and fortune. Can you triumph over a Disaster on Everest?

Control the movement of your guides and climbers as they navigate the treacherous ridges, ascend the technically-challenging Hillary Step, and strive to reach the "top of the world!" Maximize the use of your guides' special abilities to safely escort your clients as the storm approaches. Manage the events on the mountain or lose your well-paying important clients to the inevitable disasters that await.

Advanced and optional game rules add client traits and unique travel company abilities.

Followed up and expanded by:

 Disaster on K2

item.description:
From the Childrens BBC 'Deadly 60' television program comes the official card game.

Collect 165 different cards of the worlds deadliest creatures and face them off against one and other using the stats printed on the card.

Each card contains a picture and name of a deadly animal, along with their stats based on 'Size, Speed, Weapons and Deadliness'. Also on each card is a 'Deadly Fact' about the animal.

Play three different types of games, Deadly Attack, Skull Strike and Habitat Hunt. All game rules and more information can be found at www.deadly60cards.com

Available as 8 card randomized booster packs.

Though similar to Top Trumps, this game differs in its various play-styles as well as collectible format.

The rules are set at an operational rather than a tactical level. The system is based upon a detailed analysis of ship and weapon abilities for the period. Gunnery uses a fire effect table with no to hit rolls. Torpedo attacks also use a simple system. The game effects represent those significant hits which cripple a ship’s ability to fight effectively. The ground scale of 1 cm to 500 yards (4 cm to the nautical mile) and time scale of 1 turn to 15 minutes enable realistic movement and gun ranges, combined with the problems of locating and identifying the enemy.

The system incorporates national skill ratings for commanders and crew, effects of weather and night, radar, hidden movement and spotting, carrier and air operations.

The rules come complete with 700+ ships and aircraft covering the era from 1890 through to 1945.

(Publishers Description)

name.value: Piratas do Caribe: No Fim do Mundo

item.description:
Davy Jones against Jack Sparrow. The first hides the ark and dangers while the other must collect ark and keys while fighting monsters and other foes. But the task is not easy because Jack Sparrow can use it´s special barnacle only a few times and even so he cannot see everything!

It is a beautiful game, has lots of chits, a special barnacle with red lenses, a mask and a decent board with a panel in between.

The player Davy Jones must hide dragons, giant squids, pirate ships, two empty islands, one island with an ark and one island with keys. Jack Sparrow must move his ship, one square at a time, trying to find out the ark and the keys. Each time Jack reaches a monster, the skull marker move one space and he can take a look at the other board with the barnacle. If he reaches a pirate ship he can fight or flee. If he chooses to run, the skull marker move one space. If he chooses to fight he must throw a special dice. If the value is higher than the pirate, he defeats it, if it is lower or equal, he looses a coin. 
Jack wins the game if he finds the ark and the keys. Davy Jones wins the game if Jack runs out of coins or if the skull marker reaches ten.

item.description:

The players in the game act as gang leaders who control those or other subway lines. The goal of the player is to make your own clan dominant. item.description:
Trigger!/Déclic !? is a (French) party game testing your reaction and coordination abilities. The game is easy to learn and provides a vivid atmosphere with lots of laughter.

To prepare the game, a plastic disk is placed in the centre of the table and each player marks one of his hands "true" and the other "false" (or one can say that the right hand is "true" and the left hand is "false").

In a turn, a question is read out loud and all the players have to answer with "true" or "false" as fast as possible, using their hands. For instance, if the answer is "true", one places his right hand on the plastic disk, as such creating a pile of hands on top of the disk. Please mind that the answer to the question might vary as a function of the number of players, the players itself, etc (see below). Mind that once you've put your hand, you cannot change your answer anymore.

Once all players have answered the question, i.e. have placed one of their hands on the pile of hands, scoring begins. The upper hand scores +1 point if its answer is correct or -1 point if its answer is incorrect. The second hand (from the top) will score +2 if its answer is correct or -2 if its answer is incorrect, and so on. For instance, in a 8 player game, the lower hand (on the plastic disk) scores +8 points for a correct answer or -8 points for an incorrect answer.

Players really have to take risks to improve their score, answering quickly and so having their hand smashed.

To give you an idea of the questions, there are several types:
Concerning the reader of the question (I am a man)
Concerning the player (You have a dog)
Concerning the environment/location (We play in a bar)
General questions (King Kong was an ape)

The game ends as soon as a player has scored a specific number of points, e.g. 30 points in a 8 player game.

Additional rules for some variations are included (like changing hands and playing in teams).

Reimplemented by:

 Hand aufs Herz

item.description:
In this epic ‘Print and Play’ board game you will play as either Jack, Kate, Sawyer or Hurley, as you travel around the island encountering not only fellow 815 survivors but also the island’s natives known as the ‘Others’. You may even come across polar bears, boars or the mysterious and deadly Smoke Monster.
As well as being uniquely structured to encompass the events of 6 seasons of LOST, this game is very heavy on theme and detail.
The sheer depth of the game, and the large number of Encounter cards, ensures that even after several plays there will still be more surprises left for you.
So step aboard Flight 815 and be prepared to begin the ultimate LOST experience...

A summary of play
You will start the game rolling a die and moving around the outer track of the Island Game Board, visiting locations such as the Barracks, the Cockpit section, the Black Rock and the Hatch. When rolling the ‘Eye’ symbol you do not move and should instead draw one of your Flash-backwards card (later in the game Flash-forwards and Flash-sideways cards are used). Your ‘Flash’ cards usually instruct you to increase or decrease your Skill points or gain Fate points.

When you visit certain locations, and have encounters, the marker on the story track will be steadily advanced. When the story track reaches certain points, changes will be made to the game; for example the Encounter Deck being used may change to another one, or certain Friends counters may become de-activated.
The story track will also instruct you and the other players to move to one of the separate game boards or a different game track on the main board.

As you progress through the various stages of the game, the Encounter decks will continually change so that you meet people and find items from the different seasons of the LOST saga. Also your chosen character’s skill points will gradually improve making future challenges easier, and you will gain all important Fate points.

You will receive Mystery Counters as rewards. Each of the various mysteries depicted (for example Jacob, the Numbers) is made up of a set of 5 cards. If you can collect a complete set, they can be traded in for additional Fate points.

Eventually the action will move to the centre track on the game board where one of the players will be chosen to succeed Jacob. The end game will then commence. Along with the other players you must defeat the Man in Black and play the Desmond card at the Light Source space in order to save the island and win the game. Whichever player has the most Fate points at this point is declared the winner, but should your fail and allow the Man in Black to survive, all players lose the game.

LOST ‘The End’ is a Print and Play board game from MM Games, for 2 to 4 players, due for release in November 2010.
It takes on average between 2 to 3 hours to complete a game.

This game is non-profit making and is a fan-made project intended for the entertainment of fans of the the TV series LOST. No copyright infringement is intended.

The Good Sirs is a 2 player debate game between cats and dogs. All nonsense aside this is a very strategic game. Players have to allocate their actions to gain debating resources. These debating resources help them persuade the audience on certain topics of the city planning debate such as the budget, healthcare, and municipal buildings. The player who sways the most audience members wins the game, but beware to not get carried away, because for every audience member you get, you lose an action.

A strategic domino game for 2 to 5, played with traditional Western Dominoes. Designed to provide a tense, tactical, and strategic game in a quick time frame, played solely with dominoes, that does not require pencil and paper or any other components for tracking score.

In Ivory Tower, players strive to construct their own ivory tower and make it the most impressive in the group by placing dominoes with sequential pips following specific rules and scoring based on numbers of dominoes included in this personal "tower." A few extra dominoes are available for purchase in the "shop" each turn, leading some playtesters to affectionately refer to Ivory Tower as "Domino Alhambra" (which is not inaccurate in terms of the feel, but the novel and simple game mechanics actually create a fast and tense game that generates the kinds of difficult decisions and turn angst that is more akin to games like Battleline, Lost Cities, and the Keltis series).

Depending on the number of players, varying configurations ranging from Double 6 to Double 9 dominoes are used.

Child-sized dominoes designed with colorful pictures to encourage your children to learn numbers, counting, colors, and to associate common objects.

Included in this game are 28 dominoes, each with an animal on the right and an animal shelter on the left. The objective of this game is to match the animal to its proper shelter.

How to play:
-Place all the dominoes upside down on the playing surface
-Each player draws 7 dominoes and sets them up in front of himself. The remaining dominoes constitute the bank.
-Determine the starting player. The game begins with the play of the first domino.
-The next player must fine one of the two playable dominoes. It must be played to the left or the right of the starting domino.
-If the next player does not have a playable domino, one is drawn from the bank. If the domino drawn is playable, it may be played. If not playable, that turn to play is lost.
-The game is to proceed in this manner until a player is out of dominoes. The first player out of dominoes is declared the winner.

Source: Back of the box, Directions

Similar to Picture Dominoes except that each number-picture is divided up into two separate items that can only be combined a specific way.

This game entry is a catch-all for games where some scrap of data exists – a picture in a catalog, or the game box itself – but for which not enough information is known for the game to be added to the BGG database. This entry serves as a repository for images and information for BGG users who want to research these games toward the goal of gathering enough information to include them in the database.

To participate, you can:


 Upload images of unidentified games to this page.
 Start a thread for a particular unidentified game, including whatever information you might have.
 Visit the Unidentified Games Geeklist for an overview of games currently being researched.


Please help if you can!

Also a useful catch all for gamers listing their games played but where they have insufficient information to recall which actual game it was.

name.value: Is This Just Another Bug Hunt

item.description:
From the rules Introduction:
"Is this going to be a stand-up fight, sir, or another bug hunt" - Hudson
These rules are inspired by the films Aliens (tm). They can be played solo as the Aliens are all generated by dice rolls. Two possible games can be played:
(1) The players are Colonial Marines who are exploring a base where a group of colonists have settled. Earth has lost all contact with the colonists. The marines are sent to check the base out.
(2) The Colonial Marines are planetside defending a group of settlements where contact has been made with the bugs.
Further scenarios may be created too if preferred, use the films for ideas. Any scale of figure will do from 10mm to 25mm, a collection of D6 are required. Measurements used are by squares if using floorplans otherwise substitute inches for squares.
Now includes Alien background history and Miniature Figures available."

Players run a squad of space Marines through a derelict space base or landscape attempting to eliminate as many Aliens as possible and eventually eliminating the Queen. Elimination of the Queen constitutes a victory. Each turn the space Marine player is allotted Action Points to spend that turn on movement and attacks. Aliens are controlled by the game system using tables. There are a number of tactical details that the player can manipulate to gain an advantage over the Aliens such as bringing Androids to fix equipment, special weapons, and autoturrets. Rules also cover acid splashes, line of sight and Command.

Rat Six is a solo wargame depicting the actions of teams of Allied soldiers entering the Viet Cong's extensive tunnel systems for the purposes of flushing out and/or eliminating enemy combatants. The soldiers were known as Tunnel Rats and the team commander was codenamed Rat Six.

The game employs an Action Points game mechanic. The tunnel layouts and encounters are determined by die rolls and tables. Using the tables a player moves a team of Tunnel Rats through the tunnel complex eliminating enemies and mapping the tunnels as play progresses. Action points are spent for movement and for attack/defense. Victory is achieved when the entire tunnel complex is free of Viet Cong. Individuals in the teams are armed with various period small arms and team members may have to be "pulled out" of the tunnels if wounded. Game may be used with miniatures and play area movement is square to square.

Rules were originally published in The Gauntlet #10.

Softcover book with rules for science fiction tabletop encounters.

No dice are ever used with these rules. The approach is that each weapon or tested action has what's called "The Solution". The Solution is a range of numbers from which each player chooses one of those numbers and writes it down on a piece of paper. In order to be successful, the attacking (or testing) player must match the defending player's choice for that Solution. So, for example, if a Solution is listed at 4, each player chooses either a 1, 2, 3, or 4 for that Solution. If player A chooses 2, player B must also choose 2 in order to succeed. If he instead chooses 1, 3, or 4 the test fails. Better characters will have lower solutions (1 or 2) and worse characters can have solutions ranging as high as 8 or 9.

A discard game for 2 players, using two standard decks, usually with identical backs but this is not strictly necessary.

Prepare two packs (to be played alternately in rounds) by discarding all Aces, separating into red and black piles and then swapping one red and black nine over, which becomes the [b]Comet[/b] in each pack.

Shuffle one pack and deal 18 to each player, discarding the remaining 12. Play can now begin.

The starting player places a card of his choosing in the middle. This can be one or more of the same value. The other player must now put a card or cards of one greater value (i.e. 6s on 5s, Js on 10s, all cards must be the same rank); if they are unable to do so there is a 'stop'. As Kings are high (no Aces), a King will also force a stop. At which point the player who played last starts the run again with any card(s) of their choice.

The aim of the game is to get rid of your cards, and scoring is
accumulative, with the winner in each round scoring the total number of pips in his opponent's hand (court cards score 10).

Playing the comet

The comet is a wild card and can be played with a group or on its own. It always forces a stop.

If a player wins the round and his opponent still holds the comet, the winning player scores double (the comet will therefore count as 18 points).

If a player wins by playing the comet, he scores double also. If however a player wins the round by playing the comet as a 9, his score is quadrupled.

[Rules taken from "The complete Book of Card Games" published by Hamlyn]

Children's game about Hui Buh, a famous ghost from a children's audiobook series. The active player closes his/her eyes and the evil count is hidden behind one of the seven walls. The active players then opens his/her eyes and takes out as many walls as he/she wants, but if the count is unveiled, the turn ends. If the player stops in time, he/she can perform the action on the wall pieces he/she drew. These actions include moving forward 1/2/3 spaces, using a secret corridor that forms a short cut, or finding a key to that corridor (the latter two only work together).
The first player to reach the finish line is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Trivia card game about wine. The game consists of 55 cards with three questions. For each question, four answers are provided. At the start of the game, the players agree which question from each card is used (i.e. the first from each card - there are no categories). Players take turns reading out the questions. The first player to answer correctly gets the card. When all cards are used, the player with most cards is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Educational pattern recognition game for young children. The cards have two sides. One side contains four pictures, the other side a written word.
The active player needs to find a hand card that differs from another played card by only one element; either one picture or one letter. His/her neighbor to the left looks for a card at the same time; if he/she is faster, he/she says "Raus die Maus" and it is his/her turn next. The goal is to get rid of one's cards.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Roll and Move game with social and creative elements. The basic rules are simple: Roll a die and move forward the appropriate number of fields, then perform the action that the target field demands.
The actions are not just referring to the game itself (such as letting someone pass, skip a turn etc.), but some are also pledges about things one wants to do in the future, while others just encourage players to talk about personal matters. Winning (reaching the last field) is not supposed to be important in this game.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

From the publishers description: Each player has 2 racing chicken. The goal of the game is to reach the top of the hill with the chicken. But the other players try to hinder the player and make him fall back.

It is mostly a roll and move game with dice and cards. Racing style - chicken need to climb a 3D-hill while avoiding to hit into other players "chicken".

This game is basically a 2, 3, or 4-player version of Shut the Box. Each player rolls dice to close out numbers with a combination of the total of the dice or the numbers on the dice individually. The goal is to close out all the numbers from 1-9.

Hit N' Miss has a plastic game board with a built-in felt-lined dice tray. This game uses marbles as markers, 10 for each player. Only two colors are used, blue and red. Players with the same color marbles may choose team play, though they may also play individually.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A good overview and quick hands gives payoff!

Many slightly different card pairs litters the table face down. When the cards are turned you need quick reaction. The quickest player wins the pair.

At first glance this looks like a game of memory, but the card pairs are a bit different. One player starts by turning one tile, and play continues this way around the table until two matching tiles are face up. As soon as anyone sees the match, everyone tries to smack their hands down on the oldest matching tile (i.e. not the one just turned). The quickest can claim the tile pair.

Note: Tiles are _not_ turned face-down again, so the amount of face up tiles increases during the game.

The game ends when the last pair is gone. The winner is the one with the most claimed tiles.

The Bering Sea... home to Alaskan Crab. Players manage the crew onboard a crab fishing vessel in search of this valuable delicacy in the Bering Sea. Once over a crab fishing ground, the crew sets crab pots with the hopes of scoring a large catch. After some time soaking in the cold icy waters, the crew returns to retrieve their crab pots. Will the crab pots be chock full of crab or will they be empty?

Unfortunately, fishing for crab isn't just about setting and retrieving crab pots. The crew must repair breakdowns caused by storms that wreak havoc to the crab vessel systems and even it's precious cargo. From the North, an ice pack creeps down and invades the crab fishing ground. Drifting in the sea are ice flows that wreak havoc on crab pots. As the season progresses, the temperature drops causing crab vessel systems to fail if too far North, and the value for crab slowly drops challenging the crew to work hard to quickly fish the crab grounds.

Finally, after the crab fishing season is over, each player determines who is the most profitable and has earned the bragging rights for the season.

Will you be "On the Crab"?

Winner of the Congress of Gamers - Best Game for the 2010 Rio Grande Design Contest

A player asks a question, which must be answered with yes or no by a fellow player. Before the asked one answers, the remaining fellow players must guess what he or she will answer. Coincidents bring points.

Three games for the exercise of the language ability.
“Drawing game”:
A player takes a card, other players can´t see the picture on it. Now he gives instructions to the other players, after which they after-draw the design exactly. 
“Story game”:
From an impact of 36 cards a player draws any number of cards, until two people show up. Now he considers, in which order these cards show a story, and tells this story. Afterwards the 36 cards are shown and the other players try to find the used cards.
“Description game".
A player draws from 36 cards as many as desired, on which different designs are to be seen. He must describe this card in such a way that the other players can find it out from the entire deck.
The task, which offers the game to each player, consists of developing and/or completing a certain number of square equations on a board of 8x8 squares.

It is a brazilian dexterity game. From the game box: "A equilibrium game for cool blooded persons" In this game you prepare a mountain of rings and balls, and on your turn, you must remove a selected ball from a ring, without leeting the mountain go down.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
From the back of the box:

"Winnie the Pooh Peek-a-boo is an entertaining memory game for very young children. Children from the age of three can play along. Peek through the holes and try to remember which of the covers hide goodies belonging to Pooh's friends.

Collect the most cards and win the game."

Theme: Winnie the Pooh theme with pretty much all of the main characters involved.

Game-play: The game starts with 30 tiles all open (!). Then the 6 covers, which all have 1-3 peek holes in them, are place over 6 of the tiles, and the person placing them names the tiles. Then the next player starts, throwing a die with 6 colors, and guessing what lies under the tile with the cover of that color.

Goal: To get as many guesses right as possible. Each correct guess gets you that tile. The player with most tiles at the end of the game wins.
